summary: This compilation from the 1989–1990 Review of Ghana Law presents several personal injury cases involving fatal road accidents heard in various High Court divisions across Ghana. The judgments focus on quantifying compensation for loss of dependency, loss of expectation of life, funeral expenses, pain and suffering, and special damages. Awards vary significantly based on the deceased's age, occupation, income, number of dependants, and duration of survival post-accident. Notably, even minors with income-generating activities were awarded for loss of expectation of life. The courts applied multipliers (e.g., years' purchase) to calculate dependency losses, and recognized claims by widows, children, and elderly parents. All cases were civil claims for damages arising from negligence, primarily in road traffic contexts.
verdict: Plaintiffs awarded damages in all cases
citations: APPIAH v BAFFOUR (Aryee Ag J, Accra, 26 July 1989)
ASARE v ASANTE (Aryee Ag J, Accra, 5 April 1989)
DAGBUIE v ASAFO (Amuah J, Ho, 24 February 1989)
DRAMANI v SOLI (Aryee Ag J, Accra, 16 December 1988)
IDRISA v SAOUD BROTHERS AND SONS (Adjabeng J, Sekondi, 23 December 1987)
KOOMSON v EDU (Adjabeng J, Sekondi, 20 January 1989)
NARH v TEYE (Ammah J, Accra, 14 April 1989)
rationaleHighlights: Awards based on deceased's income, dependants, and years of expected contribution
Loss of dependency calculated using multi-year purchase method
Loss of expectation of life awarded even for minors with earning capacity
Funeral and medical expenses reimbursed as special damages
Pain and suffering recognized in conscious victims
Dependents include spouses, children, and elderly parents
Higher awards for higher earners with more dependants
Costs often excluded from main award
confidenceNotes: All cases are from lower courts or unspecified appellate levels; none are from the Supreme Court despite the file path. Data is drawn from a compiled legal review publication, likely accurate but secondary in nature.
